subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
Personal Statement for Economics (maybe econ and phil)
Why do you want to study this course or subject?Bottom of Form
I first realised the concept of trading time for money when my family acquired a small business – I noticed the difference between labour and capital, and the emphasis on building assets that generate income irrespective of hours worked, which shifted us to financial stability. I reflected on the value of money and how economic choices affect the quality of life.
 Travelling between my family's roots in China and the US exposed me to distinct contrasts between developing and advanced economies. I was curious to how cities develop to global economic centres and where wealth originates: Why did Shanghai's trajectory diverge from Beijing's? Why did the cost of dragon fruit in Toronto and Manchester differ so vastly? I concluded that the answers lay not in geography, but in complex systems of supply chains, policy, and global trade.
To explore this further, I completed Oxford's PPE insight on Springpod, exploring how policy, philosophy, and geography shape economic outcomes. Charles Tilly's idea 'the state made the war, and the war made the state' fascinated me by the effects of conflict and grew my interest in how various states developed. 
Reading 'Can't we just print more money?' framed economics as the study of choices. I discovered that my own mindset was inherently economic. My decision to stay at my school for sixth form despite rational instincts to leave, highlighted the tension between logical cost-benefit analysis and irrational human biases. It illustrates how human behaviour deviates from pure rationality often to the choice that proves makes us happiest, as explored in Dan Ariely's talk, 'are we in control of our own decisions?'. 
Sheremeta's TED talk 'The pursuit of happiness' showed that while income raises happiness, it plateaus. Money buys comfort, not fulfilment, and does so at the cost of our most finite resource: time. Personally, running our restaurant increased income but reduced time together. Professor Jiang's lecture 'Consumerism is the perfection of slavery' made me question whether modern economies encourage endless consumption and labour at the cost of genuine happiness. I saw the parallels, how social comparisons drive consumer choices, just as competition over resources drives national conflicts. I pondered the structure of our labour market, consumerism, and trade-offs we make chasing financial stability. Whether modern consumer capitalism truly enables a good life, or if wealth truly substitutes for time. Our lives are structured around earning, consuming and competing. We are conditioned to believe that life should revolve around making money, as though wealth is the ultimate source of happiness. It seems that money is an invisible trap, necessary for survival, yet in pursuing it, capable of consuming our time, relationships and individuality.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?
From enjoying calculus in A level maths, and analysing the choices of my family, I modelled a production function to quantify the relationship between labour input and output. Using calculus, I derived the marginal product of labour, formalising the law of diminishing returns we experienced: each additional hour worked brought smaller gains in income at a greater cost to wellbeing. This application of mathematics to a personal economic problem solidified my desire to learn the formal econometric tools needed to measure such trade-offs on a larger scale. 
What else have you done outside your education and Why are these experiences useful?
Curious about the choices of consumers, I researched the global spike in demand for matcha. I observed a cherished part of my heritage become a commodified trend, prioritising aesthetics over authenticity. Managing marketing for businesses showed me how digital platforms shape consumer behaviour; now I saw them reshape a global market. A drink once dismissed as tasting like grass, became desirable through social influence. Businesses capitalised on this trend with inferior matcha at inflated prices for profit. The demand created shortages and pressured farmers, rooted not in genuine appreciation, but in social media-amplified herd behaviour. This phenomenon highlights the tension between authenticity and profit, tradition, and trend, showing that economics is not just abstract supply and demand, but the study of how technology and consumerism drive markets and reshape value itself. 
Working in my family's restaurant, from waitressing to bookkeeping has further shown me how these economics principles operate in real-world businesses. I began to see each business as a mini economy. By its internal ecosystem, from kitchen staff to online ordering platforms. Supply and demand dictated operations, strategic decisions mirrored game theory. Shadowing at my mother's salon showed how customer experience influenced demand. To broaden my perspective, I completed Springpod work experience with Heathrow Airport and Barclays, gaining insight into organisational strategy and large-scale financial systems.

Above all, my years at a specialist music boarding school from the age of eight taught me to recognise opportunity cost and trade-offs in a very practical sense, while also allowing me to develop my own human capital through intensive training in music.
Balancing a demanding schedule of academics simultaneously with music developed strong time management and perseverance. Studying violin in a pressured environment required hours of practice and rehearsals, where I built concentration and teamwork. Completing both my Music GCSE and A-level a year early proves my resilience. 
As a String and Junior House prefect, it is rewarding to apply the skills I learnt growing up in order to support younger students and transfer my discipline into guidance. Through organising events and supporting younger students from my roles, I have practised my organisational, communication, and leadership skills. Beyond my A levels, I am currently studying AmusTCL, which has navigated me to independently research and study set works, therefore giving me an insight to the levels of study required at university.  
These experiences have shaped my interest in how incentives, efficiency, and choices influence behaviour, businesses, and economic issues. I am excited to deepen this understanding by studying economics at university, combining theory with quantitative analysis, to better explain the systems that affect society.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The statement is below average for LSE level. Theories are weak, writing is very descriptive, economics level doesn't go beyond A-level understanding. Contains many rhetorical questions and under-explained sections with not much development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Read economics sources at university level, develop theories properly with explanations, reduce descriptive narrative and increase analytical depth

feedback_items.weak_passage: I first realised the concept of trading time for money when my family acquired a small business – I noticed the difference between labour and capital
feedback_items.your_feedback: This doesn't sound like somebody who wants to study economics or has understood it well. The jump to 'difference between labour and capital' is a very weird thought to have - people who study economics would not think this way.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this opening entirely. It's not salvageable and doesn't demonstrate genuine economics understanding.

feedback_items.weak_passage: building assets that generate income irrespective of hours worked
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a massive oversimplification of how capital and asset generation actually works in economics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Why did Shanghai's trajectory diverge from Beijing's? Why did the cost of dragon fruit in Toronto and Manchester differ so vastly?
feedback_items.your_feedback: These rhetorical questions are not specific enough and you don't answer them. You then say you 'concluded' but gave no reasoning to reach a conclusion - you just gave rhetorical questions.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove rhetorical questions or actually answer them with specific economic analysis and evidence

feedback_items.weak_passage: I concluded that the answers lay not in geography, but in complex systems of supply chains, policy, and global trade
feedback_items.your_feedback: This comes out of nowhere with no support. When did you say it was geography? This is the same as saying 'apples, oranges, and pears' - not a targeted answer to your questions. The logic doesn't flow.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide actual reasoning and evidence for your conclusion instead of jumping to it

feedback_items.weak_passage: Charles Tilly's idea 'the state made the war, and the war made the state' fascinated me
feedback_items.your_feedback: If you include quoted words, you must explain what you mean and what you understand that to be. Otherwise it's just a statement with no explanation or link to any issue. It's entirely pointless as written.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add detail explaining what this means, what your thoughts are, and link it to a specific economic issue

feedback_items.weak_passage: My own mindset was inherently economic
feedback_items.your_feedback: This actually means nothing and is a red flag. Should be cut entirely.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this phrase

feedback_items.weak_passage: My decision to stay at my school for sixth form despite rational instincts to leave, highlighted the tension between logical cost-benefit analysis and irrational human biases
feedback_items.your_feedback: You haven't explained why you were leaving or what the link is. Makes no sense. The reader has no idea what you're talking about regarding your decision to leave. Cannot follow your story.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either explain the full context with specific costs and opportunity costs, or remove this example entirely

feedback_items.weak_passage: You do a lot of name dropping. You then mention Dan Ariely and then we're straight onto a Sheramita TED Talk. And then in this you've got Professor Jiang
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're listing off names without ever actually explaining anything. No development of ideas from any of these sources.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pick fewer sources and actually develop each one properly with explanation of theory and your analysis

feedback_items.weak_passage: Money buys comfort, not fulfilment, and does so at the cost of our most finite resource: time
feedback_items.your_feedback: Is this your opinion or something the TED Talk said? Cannot tell if this is analysis or just summary.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify whether this is from the source or your own analysis

feedback_items.weak_passage: running our restaurant increased income but reduced time together
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're forcing theoretical economics and academic stuff into your personal life. You cannot do that. It just doesn't work. You're supposed to explain and develop ideas within the context of academic content, not jump around like this.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove personal anecdotes trying to force economic theory. Instead discuss theory in academic context with proper sources

feedback_items.weak_passage: Are you gonna answer that question? Are you going to bring in some sources to get me there?
feedback_items.your_feedback: Multiple rhetorical questions throughout this section that are never answered. You ask if modern economies encourage endless consumption - but provide no answer or sources.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Answer your own questions with evidence and analysis, or don't ask them

feedback_items.weak_passage: I saw the parallels, how social comparisons drive consumer choices, just as competition over resources drives national conflicts
feedback_items.your_feedback: Where did you see that? Where did you see the parallels? No evidence or source provided. This doesn't follow logically from what you said before.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide specific source or study that demonstrates these parallels

feedback_items.your_feedback: A proper section should be: 1) a point, 2) a source, 3) explain the author's conclusion, 4) what do you think, 5) another source to support or conflict, 6) explain theory clearly, 7) link to EPQ or extracurricular, 8) explain methodology and exact steps, 9) conclusion. Your sections do none of this - they're just a series of thoughts and innermost reflections, not academic writing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure all sections to follow proper academic format with point-source-explanation-analysis-conclusion structure

feedback_items.weak_passage: From enjoying calculus in A level maths, and analysing the choices of my family, I modelled a production function to quantify the relationship between labour input and output
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're trying to force family choices into academic economics again. All of this about production function and MPL is total nonsense in this context.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead say: 'I studied this MOOC which discussed [statistical modelling tool], explain what research they were trying to find, explain how they found it, explain theory about how this modelling works.' That would be much better and stronger.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This is, I mean, LSE is definitely not gonna go for this
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's not academic writing - it's just innermost thoughts without structure. Not suitable for LSE level. Most sections are not salvageable.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Complete rewrite needed focusing on: proper source development, clear theory explanation, academic structure, reduced personal narrative, increased analytical depth

feedback_items.your_feedback: You are clearly a passionate student who has done readings. This critique is only about the writing, not your intelligence. Most students just don't know how to write these statements properly, which is why it ends up like this.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: You have several months before submission (not applying to Oxbridge). Use this time to completely restructure following proper academic format.
feedback_items.strong_passage: you clearly are passionate for your subject, and you've got a lot of good things here
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows the student has done work and has genuine interest, just needs to learn how to present it properly

subject: Veterinary Medicine
statement_full_text:
Why Do You Want To Study This Course/Subject?
During a greyhound dental procedure at a small animal hospital, I saw how untreated periodontal disease can cause lasting pain and wider health problems. Looking beyond immediate treatment, I the vet highlighted the impact that preventative care could have in sparing an animal years of discomfort. I noticed how vets often consulted textbooks, as every animal presents as an individual case; sometimes with symptoms rather than a clear disease; which showed me the profession relies on weighing evidence to reach the best decision. After this placement, I was offered a Saturday job at the clinic, where I had to maintain a sterile environment to protect patients and staff. At a large animal practice, I applied the same preventative principles whilst I administered bluetongue vaccinations, disinfecting equipment and changing gloves between animals. This multifaceted nature of veterinary medicine excites me as it allows me to indulge into practical skills, scientific depth and responsibilty simultaneously.

How Have Your Qualifications and Studies Helped You To Prepare For This Course Or Subject?
While on a placement in a large animal clinic in Germany, I saw the effects of intensive production when a bull developed rumen bloat after a switch to a high-concentrate diet to improve meat quality. After the vet inserted a trocar and cannula, I injected an anti-inflammatory and antibiotics, appreciating the responsibility. I later read Yusu Wang's journal on feedlot bloat pathogenesis, comparing the free gas and foam formation theories. I found evidence supporting the latter theory to be more convincing as the rumen fistulated goat experiment provided visual evidence of foam production rather than free gas. In contrast, I thought the gas overproduction theory lacked direct experimental support and relied on assumptions about why normal eructation would fail to remove excess gas which seemed less conclusive to me. This sparked my interest in biotechnology's role in balancing productivity with welfare. I received "highly commended" being one if the top 10 entries to the Minds Underground Veterinary essay competition where I explored reproductive technologies and gene editing. Learning about induced pluripotent cells led me to Jonathan Slack's "A Short Introduction to Stem Cells"...

What Else Have You Done To Prepare Outside of Education, and Why Are These Experiences Useful?
At a veterinary masterclass I attended, a vet's account of dehorning rhinos highlighted the importance of focusing efforts for maximum impact, an idea echoed in the "Biology for a Better Tomorrow" course by Leaf that I completed. This course introduced me to AI's potential in medicine but lacked detail on drug development, hence I watched a TEDx talk on how AI accelerated COVID-19 clinical trials by improving site selection and patient recruitment. However, a VetTimes podcast on rising anti microbial resistance causing a rise of bovine respiratory issues led me to consider the prospect of AI-driven treatments. I then learned from a Nature article how AI and compound screening are being used to develop antibiotic potentiators, which could enhance existing antibiotics and protect animal health. During a Cambridge vet residential, I practised feeling inside a model cow's rectum and removed nails from a model horse's shoe, reinforcing my desire to combine scientific principles with practical skills. This led me to volunteer at a stable for my Gold DofE, gaining confidence with horses through feeding, grooming, and exercising them. Furthermore, I spent a summer working at a livery stable, where I enhanced my practical skills in animal care and developed my communication skills by regularly interacting with clients. During a consultation, I saw a vet compassionately discussing treatment costs and euthanasia with a client whose dog had many issues including epilepsy. This demonstrated the importance of empathetic communication to help clients navigate emotionally and financially difficult decisions, whilst ensuring they feel informed and supported. I am drawn to veterinary medicine because it's multifaceted nature let's me combine scientific depth, practical skill and responsibility for animal welfare.

feedback_items.your_feedback: There's not enough academic content for very academic universities. The academic content present is lacking in development. You have the right levels of work experience, but you're using many words to say obvious or simple things.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Increase academic content proportion and depth. Be more concise with work experience descriptions to make room for deeper academic analysis.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I noticed how vets often consulted textbooks, as every animal presents as an individual case; sometimes with symptoms rather than a clear disease; which showed me the profession relies on weighing evidence to reach the best decision
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a very obvious statement. You've used so many words to say 'from this, I learned that vets must evaluate the evidence in front of them to make the best decision.' That's all you've said in all those sentences. The conclusion is not what you want to show tutors - you should show nuanced, developed understanding.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense to: 'From this I learned vets must evaluate evidence to make the best decision.' Use saved space for deeper physiological science or specific case details.

feedback_items.weak_passage: After this placement, I was offered a Saturday job at the clinic, where I had to maintain a sterile environment to protect patients and staff. At a large animal practice, I applied the same preventative principles whilst I administered bluetongue vaccinations
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole first paragraph is fairly lengthy but you've actually only said two things: preventative care is important, and you did various activities. You haven't told me anything insightful about what a vet actually does beyond sterilizing things and evaluating evidence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Before writing, list what you want to say about vet characteristics and thinking. Add insight beyond just describing activities.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I appreciated the responsibility
feedback_items.your_feedback: The Germany placement is very descriptive - just 'I did this, I did that.' Your conclusion is only 'I appreciated the responsibility' which could say so much more. There are many other things you could discuss.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add: 'I had read something in a different paper and was interested to see this at play. I realized there are other treatment methods, but we chose this one because of certain symptoms. From this I understood a vet must know innovations in surgery and medicine, and how to best treat based on symptoms and evidence.' This is more developed and nuanced.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This bit about Wang's journal on feedlot bloat pathogenesis is fine. This is your first proper academic section.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add a final sentence linking to wider science you'll study at university or modules you'll take. This would show you've researched the course.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Yusu Wang's journal on feedlot bloat pathogenesis, comparing the free gas and foam formation theories
feedback_items.why_strong: First academic section with proper source analysis and theory comparison

feedback_items.weak_passage: I received "highly commended" being one if the top 10 entries to the Minds Underground Veterinary essay competition where I explored reproductive technologies and gene editing
feedback_items.your_feedback: You mention the essay but don't actually explain it. Students tend to really underdo their essays. The essay is the quickest, easiest way to show how you think and your research level and skill.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand to include: your conclusion, methodology, research approach, supporting arguments. This should be a full section showing your thinking process.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Learning about induced pluripotent cells led me to Jonathan Slack's "A Short Introduction to Stem Cells"...
feedback_items.your_feedback: This section trails off with '...' and needs expansion. This could be part of your academic content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand this section to discuss what you learned from the book and how it connects to veterinary applications

feedback_items.weak_passage: This course introduced me to AI's potential in medicine but lacked detail on drug development, hence I watched a TEDx talk on how AI accelerated COVID-19 clinical trials...However, a VetTimes podcast on rising anti-microbial resistance...I then learned from a Nature article
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're running through ideas too quickly - bam, bam, bam, bam. You haven't explained enough about each source. You need a sentence between each source. After reading, I'm left with questions: what happened? how is that linked? You try to force links rather than expanding each idea carefully and clearly.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add sentences between: the Leaf course, the TED Talk, the podcast, and the Nature article. Explain how AI improved site selection, how that links to bovine respiratory issues, develop each connection properly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: During a Cambridge vet residential, I practised feeling inside a model cow's rectum and removed nails from a model horse's shoe
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just descriptive - 'I did this, I did that.' It's not a story or diary entry. It has to be analytical and exploring issues.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Could be moved to first paragraph as it doesn't add anything by itself and isn't a launch pad to discuss anything else

feedback_items.weak_passage: This demonstrated the importance of empathetic communication to help clients navigate emotionally and financially difficult decisions
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is too obvious and not drawing upon the traits you really need for medicine at the level expected.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Look at Cambridge module pages to understand what traits they're looking for. Go deeper than obvious observations about empathy.

feedback_items.your_feedback: If you reduce sections to key points (how a tutor reads), it shortens significantly in terms of what you're actually telling them. The first section could be condensed, giving space to expand academic sections.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reduce first section to save space. Expand: Wang's journal section, essay details, Jonathan Slack discussion, AI sources connections. Add more academic depth throughout.

subject: Politics_Development
statement_full_text:
Question 1:
A field trip to the UNDP in Georgia revealed how political systems shape development and the lives of citizens. Observing how governments in the Global South navigate within the fabric of international politics sparked my interest in the balance between governance and development and the complexity of such relationships.

This curiosity deepened when I founded a competitive debate club, exploring contested issues in depth and developing my analytical skills. One topic that proved pivotal was the effectiveness of international aid in promoting sustainable development. Initially, I believed aid could directly stimulate economic growth and social progress. However, after reading Globalization and Its Discontents by Joseph Stiglitz, I came to appreciate that development outcomes are rarely linear. His analysis of how international institutions shape economic policy to pursue their own goals highlighted the limits of aid. It made me realise that the political decisions of all actors shape the success of development initiatives and external aid, if mismanaged, can exacerbate existing crises.

This shift in perspective enhanced my understanding of the interplay between political authority and economic policy. Engaging with these ideas consolidated my interest in how governments and IGOs shape equitable and sustainable development, and motivates me to investigate these questions further through degree-level study.

Question 2:
In my IB Global Politics unit on development, I explored concepts including institutional capacity and its role in shaping development outcomes. Studying how political institutions' transparency, accountability, and effectiveness influence policy implementation allowed me to critically examine why similar development initiatives can produce very different results in different contexts.

Alongside this, I engaged with regenerative approaches to development, a critical perspective on sustainability. Although these strategies are often presented as universally beneficial, it is clear that the countries which stand to benefit are developing states lacking the resources or technology to implement them effectively. Achieving meaningful progress would rely on a form of liberalism whereby wealthier states provide support without imposing restrictive conditions, which is challenging in practice. Analysing these theories and their limits strengthened my ability to evaluate policies critically, preparing me to study these complexities at degree level.

I explored these ideas further in my extended essay on Armenian sovereignty post-2020, analysing how historical legacies and contextual challenges shaped governance and stability, and gaining a deeper appreciation for the complexity of political decision-making in post-conflict states.

Building on the research skills I developed writing my essay, I founded a student-led research journal to explore political events from multiple perspectives. Through the journal, I examined a wide range of development issues, from Costa Rica's near-carbon-neutral policies to other international initiatives, which broadened my understanding of how states may implement different strategies to achieve developmental goals.

Together, these experiences allowed me to analyse complex political challenges, evaluate competing strategies for sustainable development, and engage critically with multiple perspectives, equipping me to study these issues at university.

Question 3:
To better understand how development initiatives reach vulnerable communities, I contributed to projects addressing food insecurity at the UN World Food Programme, analysing patterns in aid distribution and assessing their effects on local communities. This experience demonstrated the influence of large IGOs, further emphasising the complexity of the interactions between actors in politics and giving me a deeper appreciation for the mechanisms and structures that underpin the field.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Is the statement suited for all courses chosen? Not really. You've only included development economics at quite a shallow level - would almost count as having no economics. Need more economics that is still politics-related since the two are very interlinked.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Include more economics content that relates to politics. The two subjects are deeply interlinked so this should be achievable without losing focus.
feedback_items.strong_passage: you are a very good writer. You know, you're very nice and clear
feedback_items.why_strong: Writing quality is strong, clear communication

feedback_items.weak_passage: a field trip, this whole top paragraph, it's a bit long. I think you could probably do some something language wise to to reduce that down a little bit
feedback_items.your_feedback: The paragraph is lengthy but doesn't contain much beyond: went to Georgia, saw how political systems shaped development, observed complexity of relationships. It's a lot of words to say just that - very summary-focused.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense language to be more efficient. The main points can be expressed more concisely.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Development outcomes are rarely linear
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a little bit vague. Could move on if your next sentence explains well, but the follow-up isn't strong enough.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Follow with more specific explanation of what non-linear development outcomes mean in practice

feedback_items.weak_passage: his analysis of how international institutions shape economic policy to pursue their own goals highlighted the limits of aid
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not the most well-developed insight. It seems obvious that international institutions shape policy for their own goals, but the link to how that limits aid isn't obvious or well-explained. You haven't developed it out super well - it's very high level.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pull out a better theory from the book. Link to something contrasting. Provide example of where it's been applied and failed. Develop the connection between institutional self-interest and aid limitations.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Political decisions of what act to shape the successive development initiatives. It's almost like the same thing, but kind of backwards
feedback_items.your_feedback: External aid if mismanaged can exacerbate crises - but what crises? Not enough good theory. Although clear you've read the book, you could pull out better insights.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify which crises. Provide concrete examples. Add substantive theory rather than high-level generalizations.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This shift in perspective enhanced my understanding of the interplay between political authority and economic policy. Engaging with these ideas consolidated my interest
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're saying the same thing over and over: complexity of relationships, fabric of international politics, political decisions shaping success, interplay between political theory and economic policy - all basically the same thing. Not learning what you've actually learned.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace repetitive summary statements with specific insights about what you learned. Show understanding rather than restating complexity.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Institutional capacity and its role in shaping development outcomes, like, how political institutions transparency and all of this stuff
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole first section is another introduction - just saying political institutions are complicated. You've already said that. Can we get into other ideas?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Skip the introduction about complexity and move directly to substantive analysis and new ideas

feedback_items.weak_passage: achieving meaningful progress would rely on a form of liberalism where wealthier states provide support without imposing restrictive conditions, which is challenging in practice
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're onto something interesting here - giving a view into how to be effective with development strategy. But you finish with 'which is challenging in practice' and stop. Then go straight back to summary mode saying analyzing theories strengthened abilities.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: After stating it's challenging, add: 'as we observed in [specific example]' to show you follow relevant blogs and current developments. Then develop this further.
feedback_items.strong_passage: achieving meaningful progress would rely on a form of liberalism where wealthier states provide support without imposing restrictive conditions
feedback_items.why_strong: Starting to engage with substantive policy proposals and solutions

feedback_items.weak_passage: Analysing these theories, strengthen my ability to evaluate policies critically. Obviously, you're not evaluating policies to that to that level
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're not evaluating policies at this level based on what's shown. The claim doesn't match the depth of analysis provided.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be more modest in claims or provide evidence of actual deep policy evaluation

feedback_items.weak_passage: analysing, you know, gaining a deep appreciation for the complexity of political decision making in post-conflict states
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is again the same thing you keep saying. The essay is underexplained - could have said more about how you constructed your argument, which is the interesting part.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand essay section to show methodology, argument construction, evidence used, and conclusions reached. This shows your thinking process.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Through the journal, I examined a wide range of development issues, from Costa Rica's near-carbon-neutral policies to other international initiatives
feedback_items.your_feedback: You list things you looked at, but would be better to list one and then go into detail about it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pick one journal topic (like Costa Rica's policies) and analyze it in depth rather than listing multiple topics

feedback_items.weak_passage: together, these experiences allow me to analyse complex political challenges, evaluate competing strategies, and engage critically with multiple perspectives
feedback_items.your_feedback: These summary sentences are a waste of space. You could use this to go into detail about your essay, journal, debate ideas, develop theory, link to high-level concepts. You're wasting so much space on generic conclusions.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut all summary sentences. Use that space (40% of statement) to develop essay, journal, debate theory in detail. Link to high-level academic concepts.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Further emphasising the complexity of the interactions between acts and politics and give me a deeper appreciation
feedback_items.your_feedback: Again with the summary about complexity and appreciation. The section before this was fine until this ending.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace with specific insight about what you learned about IGO mechanisms or aid distribution patterns

feedback_items.your_feedback: Needs work. If you cut all repetitive summary sentences, you'll reduce by 40%. With that 40%, develop ideas more. I have no idea how you think, construct arguments, how good you are at making arguments - not enough evidence shown.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove all sentences about 'complexity,' 'appreciation,' 'understanding.' Replace with: detailed essay methodology, specific debate arguments, developed theory connections, evidence of analytical thinking.

subject: Law
statement_full_text:
The conventional definition of intelligence tends to be quite limited, often reducing it to measurable metrics. In my view, contrarily, intelligence is the ability to grasp the intricate and multifaceted nature of society itself. Over the last three years, I have pursued this broader understanding by gaining insight into areas such as business, sociology, and most personally influential to me, law.
The law is not merely a set of fixed rules to ensure social order but a reflection of our progress – tangible markers of our body politic in constant motion. It is, however, important to note that the pace of this progression is often uneven. As society rapidly develops and shifts, legal reform is constrained by precedent and parliamentary primacy. I identified this tension while studying An Introduction to English Law through the University of London's MOOC in 2023. Section 4 of the Human Rights Act 1998 effectively demonstrates this: courts may make a declaration of incompatibility with fundamental rights, as seen in Ghaidan v Godin-Mendoza (2004), but this does not compel amendment. This can prolong the life of laws that no longer reflect current morality in favour of preserving parliamentary sovereignty.  Law captivates me because it demands rigorous analysis – challenging not just doctrinal coherence, but its underlying moral logic and consequential effects on society. Where strict legal frameworks collide with questions of justice and real-world outcomes, it fuels my drive to study law more deeply.
My particular interest lies where business and human rights intersect; my father and I constantly converse about corporate ethics and accountability. The conversations are where my love for corporate and commercial law arose and where I started to see how legal structures don't just sit there on paper; they actively shape the way companies behave, with their effects rippling across society and the economy. Having passionate discussions and heated debates over complex legal matters has given me purpose and motivation. Most importantly, though, it has helped form my moral compass, harnessing my belief in social responsibility.
To build a stronger foundation in this area, I completed Clifford Chance's Business and Human Rights virtual job simulation. I discovered how mergers and acquisitions, as well as litigation teams, play a legitimate role in protecting human rights – not just chasing deals or fighting lawsuits. I also found myself digging through an overwhelming amount of information, most of it not particularly useful, just to extract the relevant legal arguments. That process sharpened my research skills and made me a lot more efficient at communicating with clients in clear, focused language. This experience confirmed that law is where I want to be. It's a field that demands both analytical precision and a strong sense of ethics – exactly the kind of challenge that motivates me.
Law captivates me precisely because it forces a confrontation between ideals and reality, exposing the underlying rhythms of society. Each principle lives beyond the page, shaping the world and testing the kind of intelligence I value most.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall pretty good, especially considering you didn't get much school support. A lot of good things going on. The themes are clear, you've done the right things, you're a good writer with good sections.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus is slightly incorrect - need to remove summary statements and add specific detailed examples. Less work than you think to improve this.
feedback_items.strong_passage: a lot of good things going on, especially, I think you said that you didn't get much. I mean, it looks like school wise, you wouldn't have got the most support for this
feedback_items.why_strong: Strong foundation especially given lack of school support, good writing quality

feedback_items.weak_passage: The conventional definition of intelligence tends to be quite limited, often reducing it to measurable metrics. In my view, contrarily, intelligence is the ability to grasp the intricate and multifaceted nature of society itself
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is not the best start. Doesn't tell anything about you, relevance to law is not amazing. Not sure what that definition of intelligence has to do with anything. The entire first part is unnecessary.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this entire opening. Start directly with the MOOC observation about legal reform being strained by precedent and parliamentary primacy.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The law is not merely a set of fixed rules to ensure social order but a reflection of our progress
feedback_items.your_feedback: Too general to be interesting and you don't develop it, but also too specific to just say 'this is law.' Not the best approach.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this definition. Move straight to the specific observation from your MOOC study.

feedback_items.weak_passage: it is, however, important to note that the pace of this progression is often uneven
feedback_items.your_feedback: Why is that important to note? This question comes to mind. The connection isn't clear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either explain why it's important or remove this transition

feedback_items.weak_passage: Section 4 of the Human Rights Act 1998 effectively demonstrates this: courts may make a declaration of incompatibility with fundamental rights, as seen in Ghaidan v Godin-Mendoza (2004), but this does not compel amendment
feedback_items.your_feedback: You mention the case but don't actually explain it. Just listing it out. You start well but don't develop. The conclusion about prolonging laws doesn't follow clearly because you haven't explained enough before.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure: 'While following MOOC, I observed legal reform strained by precedent and parliamentary primacy. I studied Section 4 of HRA which says [this]. Found it interesting studying Ghaidan v Godin-Mendoza where [explain what happened and result]. Link back to main point.' This makes interest clear and shows thinking.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Law captivates me because it demands rigorous analysis – challenging not just doctrinal coherence, but its underlying moral logic and consequential effects on society
feedback_items.your_feedback: You shouldn't have to say this because the evidence and case discussion should already show you find it interesting. This becomes a meaningless sentence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this summary statement. Let your detailed analysis speak for itself.

feedback_items.weak_passage: my father and I constantly converse about corporate ethics and accountability. The conversations are where my love for corporate and commercial law arose
feedback_items.your_feedback: Describing conversations is too surface level. You haven't told me what debates, discussions, or complex legal matters you're actually having. Need example of something interesting to you.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace with: 'I particularly enjoy law's applications in business and human rights. I listen to lectures frequently. One lecture discussed [topic] and [specific case], which...' Then develop that in detail. Maybe say you enjoy debate generally, not specify it's with your dad.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Most importantly, though, it has helped form my moral compass, harnessing my belief in social responsibility
feedback_items.your_feedback: This reads like a summary sentence and anybody could say that. Doesn't add value.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence entirely

feedback_items.weak_passage: I discovered how mergers and acquisitions, as well as litigation teams, play a legitimate role in protecting human rights
feedback_items.your_feedback: Would want to know what you actually did and how they play this role. Interested to see your view on what role litigation teams play in protecting human rights. Currently too summary-level.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain exactly what you learned at Clifford Chance simulation. Talk about what roles are played specifically. You're leaving reader with lots of whys and whats that aren't explained.

feedback_items.weak_passage: That process sharpened my research skills and made me a lot more efficient at communicating with clients in clear, focused language
feedback_items.your_feedback: Tutors can infer that from your description of the work. You don't need to state it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence - show don't tell

feedback_items.weak_passage: This experience confirmed that law is where I want to be. It's a field that demands both analytical precision and a strong sense of ethics
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can say this about many subjects. Generic conclusion statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this generic statement

feedback_items.weak_passage: Law captivates me precisely because it forces a confrontation between ideals and reality, exposing the underlying rhythms of society. Each principle lives beyond the page, shaping the world and testing the kind of intelligence I value most
feedback_items.your_feedback: This doesn't add anything meaningful. Should be removed.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete entire final paragraph - it's flowery language without substance

feedback_items.your_feedback: Clear you've done good work and right things. Good writer with good sections. But focus is slightly incorrect - too much summary/shallow overview, not enough meat and detail. Leaving reader with lots of whys and whats.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Take away summary stuff and shallow overview. Get into the meat: explain exactly what you learned at Clifford Chance, what roles are played, what happened in cases, explain specific debate topics. Add not reshape. Cut parts listing skills. Less work than you think.

subject: Law
statement_full_text:
During my study of "An Introduction to English Law" through the University of London's MOOC in 2022, I became particularly intrigued by the ongoing tension between evolving societal values and the legal structures that attempt to regulate our body politic. I explored this tension by examining Section 4 of the Human Rights Act 1998, specifically its contribution to the case of Ghaidan v Godin-Mendoza (2004). In this case, the House of Lords had to decide whether a same-sex partner could inherit a statutory tenancy after the original tenant's death. Notably, while the court issued a declaration of incompatibility – explicitly recognising that the law discriminated based on sexual orientation – Parliament faced no obligation to amend the statute in response.
I find it outrageous, but fascinating that the legal system can formally acknowledge an injustice yet allow it to persist – claiming to prioritise continuity and parliamentary sovereignty over adaptation to changing morality and beliefs. When analysing the judiciary's approach to this dilemma, I observed how courts must balance the protection of individual rights against the constraints of legal doctrine and the supremacy of Parliament. This highlighted the interdependence of law and morality and demonstrated that legal reasoning does not always seamlessly align with societal impact, inspiring my interest in legal study.
My particular interest lies where business and human rights intersect. I have not had the chance to take part in official debates, so I have begun watching lectures and dissecting arguments myself. A lecture on corporate accountability really interested me and I structured my notes around two opposing positions. On one hand, corporations carry a moral responsibility to protect workers and ensure fair treatment, even if this cuts into profits. On the other hand, some argue that simply staying within statutory requirements is enough to satisfy corporate duties. This is where my love for corporate and commercial law arose and where I started to see how legal structures don't just sit there on paper; they actively shape the way companies behave, with their effects rippling across society and the economy.
To develop my understanding of this area, I recently completed Clifford Chance's Business and Human Rights virtual job simulation. This provided me with an opportunity to view legal issues from the perspective of both litigation and mergers and acquisitions teams. Within the M&A team, I analysed potential human rights risks inherent in corporate transactions, reviewing supply chain labour practices and considering the broader consequences for local communities. While with the litigation team, I undertook legal research, drafted responses to client queries, and synthesized complex evidence for presentations – always weighing not just the legal merits but the ethical and societal implications of pursuing or settling claims.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Much improved from previous version - really well done. Much cleaner, easier to follow, less repetition. Introduction is very nice.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Could split into questions 2 and 3 now. Just needs quick editing and potentially adding 1-2 sources to support arguments.
feedback_items.strong_passage: It is much improved, by the way, so really well done, much cleaner, easier to follow, less sort of repetition, you know, that all good things. The introduction's very nice as well
feedback_items.why_strong: Significant improvement in clarity, flow, and reduction of repetition

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have not had the chance to take part in official debates, so I have begun watching lectures
feedback_items.your_feedback: No need to say you haven't taken part in official debates. What would that even be? This is easy to cut to save characters.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change to: 'I have begun watching lectures and dissecting arguments; a lecture on corporate accountability...' Remove the negative framing.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I started to see how legal structures don't just sit there on paper; they actively shape the way companies behave
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can say the opposite without stating what they're not. Retains same meaning without redundancy.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change to: 'I'm interested to see how legal structures shape the way companies behave and have knock-on effects for society.' More concise and positive framing.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Could cut at least 20% through clever writing by removing things that don't add to the argument or state opposites of what you haven't done.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Take another look through for redundant phrases and negative framings. Make writing more efficient without losing meaning.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Lacking a tiny bit in sources. You have MOOC, case, and Clifford Chance simulation. You develop ideas about law well, but would like to see maybe two sources to support your arguments.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: When saying 'legal reasoning does not always align with societal impact' - bring in a study or specific case demonstrating this. When discussing how legal structures shape companies - reference a seminar or example. Not to point of name dropping, just to support arguments.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Basically there now. Just a matter of quick editing. Structure this into 3 questions yourself - don't worry about length, I can tell you what to remove.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Split current text into what you think works as question 1, 2, and 3. Submit that split version for final review.
